moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bc4 g6 4. O-O Bg7: c3?  Perhaps d3 or d4 so your bishop is not blocked and your knight can take c3
moves.5... Nc6 6. b3: b3?  Now you could have move d4 and attacked the centre.
moves.7... Qe7 8. Bg5 Nf6 9. Be3: Why retreat?  You have my knight frozen against the queen.
I'm not sure why you sacrificed your biship here.  Was this part of a plan?
moves.13... Qxf7 14. Bg5: Your bishop may have been better off on e3.  You have a potential discovered attack on a7 by moving the knight off of d4.  If you could get your queen to a4 (move b3 to b4) you have a possible checkmate with Qa7.
moves.14... Bh6 15. Nd2f3: I think you were getting tired here.  This should work, but then on your next move you take with the pawn rather than the other knight.  I think your plan was with the knight rather than opening up your king.
moves.15... Nxf3+ 16. gxf3: This is the beginning of the fall once you start opening up your king.  Things really started to unravel here.
Are you protecting your queen?  Don't forget about your king.
moves.25... Rxh3 26. f3 Rxf3 27. Rf1: This is good for me, since I am so far ahead now, I don't mind exchanging pieces.  This was your only other attacking piece.
moves.27... Rxf1+ 28. Kxf1 Ne3+ 29. Kf2 Nxf5: And now there were none.  It is really over here since you have no attacking pieces.  A stalement is always a possiblity, though.
